course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Insightful Decisions
course.description: The course helps students develop better analytical and decision making skills in approaching practical and important social and business issues. Students will derive solutions or conclusions that require critical thinking, creativity, quantitative analysis, and common sense. Cover topics in decision traps, quantitative decision models, statistical reasoning, computer tools, data-analysis techniques, etc. and, more importantly, how these decision analysis concepts and tools can be applied in a broad set of social and business problems.

reviews.author: Kwan
reviews.comment_content:
內容唔算難，主要係講一d做決定時會用到既相關concepts，例如各種bias  models, stat, game theory, probability. 多數係吹水野，logic野，有少少計數位都係以基本probability為主。因為內容都幾生活化，算係唔太學術性，較輕鬆既course。

不過唔好期望上完會幫到你做決定點，佢只係勝在夠輕鬆，教既野易入口。
reviews.comment_teaching:

reviews.comment_grading:
Grading 我唔太肯定，當年三個fds一齊讀，attendance 差唔多，但最後出grade 我地三個分別係 B／A-／C+。（C range果位final gg左）

有project present有exams.

Final 佔分最重，open book，為左個grade textbook條數走唔甩。不過由於open book 所以mean mode 都高，exam有logic位tricky位，做卷要細心睇題目。

Present 方面 creativity 同 ppt design 計分，所以好多組都會整色整水，e.g用玩game做開場，或者整個神級ppt咁，所以千祈唔好hea整d白底黑字無圖既ppt出黎玩命，盡量用有趣既方式present。in-class peer evaluation matters.
reviews.comment_workload:
你的groupmate如何，你的workload也必如何。

reviews.author: 棋子
reviews.comment_content:
The topics include:
Importance of Structured Decision Making
Decision Traps & Basic Decision Making Frameworks
Basic Decision Making Frameworks
Critical Thinking Skills
Analytical Methods
Statistical Thinking & Basic Probability
Basic Probability and Probabilistic Decision Making
Decision Trees

At the beginning, it includes some introduction of decision making in business and thinking styles. It also introduces some logic thinking. After that, you can learn some decision theory and statistics but don't expect the computation skills will be deep and difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Someone said that Ronald taught well in regular semester, but the teaching by professor GURUMURTHI in my semester is just fair. His pronounciation and accent were troubles for me.
But he is nice and used lots of daily examples in the lesson. He also encouraged us to read more before and after lessons through class activities.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not bad, but the scheme is harsh. As what I remembered he said at the beginning, the mean of the course was B-/C+, BUT the cutting of grade is by number of people instead of SD.  Since many people got near the mean, the range of B- and C+ is very narrow In this case, you got B or B+ easily if you above the mean, in contrast , you got C and C- easily if you below the mean (even less than 1 sd)

Here is my performance
Participation(20%): got  90-something% of the full
Assignment(15%): 100% Full
Group Project(15%): 9.5/15 (mean 11.6)
Final(50%): 39/80 (no stat)

Letter grade: C

Some previous comments had said that about 44/80-->B- and my friend got 48/80-->B(with same marks of assignment and projects with me), so you can see that the cutting range is very narrow. Every participation, assignment, projects are very important.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fair, include short easy online MC quizzes before each classes, 2 group assignments and 1 group project. But the annoucement of group project is a bit late (about week 9 to 10), you only have a few weeks to do at the end of semester.

The content is ok, some of the chapters are quite boring and not particularly useful. But as a Common Core SSC it's fine.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is quite interactive and uses games, quizzes and activities in almost every class to make it more fun. Yet some of the lectures turn out to be quite boring. Attending class is important as there is attendance taken through completion of group activities in every class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation: 20%
Assignments (2): 15%       
Group Project: 15%
Final Exam: 50%
The grading is fair and quite easy. Participation is easy to get 20% just by attending class. Assignments are usually problem solving, sometimes using Excel, and most students get very high marks. The group project is a bit harder. Final exam mean is quite low.
I got slightly above mean for Participation and Assignments, ~1 SD above mean for Group project, >1 SD above mean in Final exam: overall grade A+
So the final exam matters the most, as most people will have similar marks in the other sections.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is moderate. 2 Assignments are done in groups, we are given about a week to complete them and some of them require writing long answers or using Excel spreadsheets. The Group project is really time-consuming as you have to create a ~10 min video and record it. The final exam is not too difficult with enough revision from lecture notes and the textbook before the exam (all notes and the textbook can be carried inside the exam too).

reviews.author: chankatrina
reviews.title: Easy content but heavy participation
reviews.comment_content: Content is very easy to understand. Textbook is not necessary, only slides and reading materials on canvas will be tested in exams. Some models involve basic statistical calculation, but if you have taken isom 2500, it won't be difficult at all.
reviews.comment_teaching: A lot of games and discussion during lecture. Only one lecture (1.5 hrs) per week. But no cell phones / sleeping in class.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good. I scored full marks for assignment and completed all class participation. Final: 63/80 (doesn't provide mean/sd), Group project: 12.5/15 (mean: 11.6/15). Overall: A+
reviews.comment_workload: 2 group assignments + class participation + final exam + project video.

reviews.author: rjason
reviews.comment_content: Content is easy to understand and covers mostly statistics and logical problems. Memorizing terms and such are not important and the book in not needed as the course notes are easy enough to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is done through games and group activities in class that affect participation but mostly just covers course notes online so reading ahead will help gain participation marks.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair and isn't hard to get high grades at. Quizzes are done online and the final exam is open book though participation covers for a lot of the grade so attendance in class will help.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is made up of a weekly online quiz, some activities in class based on the course notes and self-formed group for a final presentation and report.

reviews.author: Little Guy
reviews.comment_content: The content for this course is easy and a lot of it is just logic and some high school probability and statistics. No need to buy the textbook, notes from course webpage is more than sufficient for examination purposes. But honestly speaking, don't expect to learn a lot of practical business knowledge from this course, it is more of an introduction to different business analytical tools and concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: GURUMURTH's voice is clear and pleasant to hear, some of the games played in class are quite interesting. Try not to skip classes too frequently because there are some in-class participation bonus points that you can get from playing those games.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is quite good. I have absolutely no background in business knowledge and managed to score an A- for the course (and I studied last minute too). No midterm exam, the final is not difficult. It is an open book test so just make sure that you familiarize yourself with the course notes and keypoints so that you can efficiently "search" for the answers during the exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is reasonable and definitely manageable. You have to do a few MC questions weekly based on a short reading of the course materials. There is a group video presentation project that you need to submit just before finals, so make sure to prepare earlier so that you have more time to study for other subjects.

reviews.author: mei you qian
reviews.title: Not a Bad SSA CC
reviews.comment_content:
Check other reviews for the full syllabus.
Could be interesting, some of them are on recent issues such as Corona. Lots of real life examples to aid the concept explanation.

BUT half the contents are quantitative including probability, stats and hypothesis testing so if you don't like math (like me), might wanna consider other SA SSC. If you took ISOM2700 with him, some contents are exactly the same (cakes, shadow price, EOQ)
If you're good at excel, you're already halfway there.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Pretty good teaching; he goes through everything step by step. He always brings up various real life examples.
Also, very clear and plain English which is a rare find in UST. Some complained he has Indian accent and they can't understand him but I think his English is darn good compared to some local or mainland profs. (maybe since he lived in the States for a while and worked at McKinsey?) He speaks slowly for everyone to follow, so you can just put it on 1.5x or stuff.
reviews.comment_grading:
He said absolute grading on the syllabus but not sure how they graded us at the end.
I got 1sd above mean for the midterm and 0.5sd above mean for the final which account for 70% of the grade. For the group project, I got a full mark - make sure you find good groupmates.
We had participation from leaving comments during the zoom lecture - you don't have to speak up, just leave your cam on and answer to his questions through the chat function.
You have weekly quizzes on Canvas and you get 2 chances so everyone would get full marks here.
I got an A at the end and for an SSC, I think the grading is generous.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not too much; short weekly quizzes, 1 real time zoom lecture and 1 weekly youtube lectures to watch with one group project.
But contents-wise, there are quite a lot to learn so if you don't follow with contents every week, you might die towards the end of the sem (finals) cuz you realize you actually have a lot to learn.
If you did stats options in IB HL Maths, you'll have even less workload.
